question.text: Thoughts on near-term food delivery business growth?

answer.text: We believe that GOV growth of 20% plus should be able to continue in the near term as well. Currently, we're trending at 27%-28% YoY growth. So that might fall a little, but by and large, we don't see any specific concerns on the demand side at this point, at least in our business.

question.text: Timeline for reaching 4% to 5% margins in food delivery?

answer.text: It's hard to comment on the exact timeline there. The idea is to grow the right way and invest in areas that we need to while we continue to scale. So, we're not working with a particular timeline as a goal and then working backward from there. But as you can see, the margin has been expanding over time while we continue to invest in growth and the long-term health of the platform. We’ll do the right things and hopefully continue on that journey on margin expansion from thereon.

question.text: Implications of adding 2,000 stores on profitability?

answer.text: At this point, we don't think that will happen, and that's why we have said that we believe the business will remain profitable. But of course, as you are saying, there are so many variables and factors at play here. From a longer-term perspective, we have fair confidence that this business can be as profitable as food delivery in terms of margin, if not more.

question.text: Updates on the District announcement?

answer.text: Nothing specific beyond what we have shared in the letter. We will continue executing on that and share more updates as and when we have them.

question.text: Impact of Google Maps APIs reduction on profitability?

answer.text: No, that is not going to impact our profitability meaningfully from here. What we've analyzed, it doesn't seem to impact our profitability meaningfully at this point.

question.text: Increase in delivery-related charges?

answer.text: There is some increase, but what you see in the P&L is a function of the amount net of customer delivery charges. Yes, customer delivery charges have been declining as our Gold proportion increases. But net of that, there is no meaningful change to the delivery cost number.

question.text: G&A increases related to new store additions in quick commerce?

answer.text: The total fixed costs that you would compute are a function of multiple factors. There could be some increase in corporate costs due to the scale of the organization increasing but at the same time, there could be a quarter where we spend a little less on marketing.

question.text: Will District be a separate app?

answer.text: We're planning to launch this as a separate app and brand. We want to take the advantage of the traffic that we have on the Zomato app.

question.text: How to differentiate in new areas against competitors?

answer.text: Our focus is to maintain a high quality of service. In the markets where we are expanding, we believe the service level, both in terms of the selection available to customers and the consistency of service, is not at the same level that we provide.

question.text: Factors affecting Blinkit take rate?

answer.text: The take rate is dependent on a lot of factors. We also had some amount of food inflation. Take rates are usually a function of many of these things. Overall, we are seeing our proportion of products outside the core category increasing, and those also have higher take rates.

question.text: Thought process on store sizes?

answer.text: Our preference is always to open larger stores, and our current inventory of the stores that we're looking to open are on average larger than the ones that we have.

question.text: Ownership structure of Blinkit stores?

answer.text: Our attempt is to make sure that every new store that we open is eventually run by a local partner.

question.text: Impact of new SKUs on Blinkit growth?

answer.text: We've been consistently adding SKUs over the last four quarters. Some of our categories have become a significant percentage of the platform, contributing meaningfully to the overall growth number.

question.text: What is the growth trend for Gold membership in terms of GOV?

answer.text: GOV growth is largely a function of order volume growth. Gold membership is increasing month on month, and we are still in the 50-55% zone for our GOV from Gold members.

question.text: Do you expect to grow at 30% GOV for the next five years?

answer.text: That statement is for our own business. From FY20 to FY24, our food delivery GOV has grown at a 30% CAGR. We aspire to grow at that rate, but the overall expectation is to at least grow at 20%.

question.text: Why have contribution margins decreased despite improved take rates?

answer.text: Higher share of Gold affected delivery charges, and factors like elections and heat waves also played a role in lower contribution margins this quarter. We expect some reversal going ahead, but rains may pressure delivery costs.

question.text: What is the expected impact of government plans for delivery partner benefits on margins?

answer.text: There is no clarity on these topics, and different states have different views. We don't expect it to impact our margins significantly, as we should be able to absorb or pass on the costs.

question.text: Can you explain the shift from mid to premium range modern retail?

answer.text: We refer to multi-store format organized retailers that cater to premium customers. There are many examples in every city, but we prefer not to name specific players.

question.text: Is the increase in capex related to Blinkit?

answer.text: It's a combination of Blinkit store scale-up and increasing warehousing capacity on the Hyperpure side, with a larger proportion related to Blinkit.

question.text: Is the working capital release of around INR 175 crores related to calendar dates?

answer.text: Yes, it's related to calendar dates and some growth in the Hyperpure business, which has positive working capital.

question.text: How broad-based was the growth in food delivery across cities?

answer.text: The growth is broad-based across top eight and non-top eight cities, driven more by supply sufficiency and onboarding new restaurants rather than AOV.

question.text: How are you solving for selection in quick commerce given the constraints?

answer.text: The experience improves with a larger selection, but we prefer not to disclose how we manage the constraints of size and delivery time.

question.text: Are there any inorganic opportunities or changes in cash return philosophy?

answer.text: No changes beyond what we've shared. We want to retain a strong balance sheet and are not considering returning cash to shareholders right now.

question.text: How much flexibility do you have to increase the platform fee in food delivery?

answer.text: We will know with time how sensitive demand is to the platform fee. We're taking it step by step and will experiment with options.

question.text: What insights can you share about the ramp-up of new stores?

answer.text: The path to profitability depends on various factors, and we track each store's journey individually. The time to profitability has been decreasing as our network expands and brand strength increases.

question.text: Are you willing to sacrifice speed and cost to increase assortment width?

answer.text: We aim to maintain speed and cost while increasing assortment width. There is no defined limit to the number of SKUs we can serve, and we continue to innovate.

question.text: How has your market share in the food delivery business been trending in south India?

answer.text: Our market is fairly broad. It's hard to have a sense of the absolute market share, but we think our penetration and share in those markets have grown meaningfully over the last two or three years. We believe we are very close to our national average even in the cities in the south where we were historically lower.

question.text: What is the broader mix of GMV in the quick commerce business, specifically the share of general merchandise and fresh, excluding dairy?

answer.text: In the Blinkit business, we don't provide that breakup.

question.text: What do you see as the hindrance to scaling from the current store count to 1,800 to 2,000 stores in the next two years?

answer.text: Our ability to execute, nothing more.

question.text: What is the plan for the cash on the books given that cash has been accruing for the last few quarters?

answer.text: There is significant value in having a strong balance sheet given that we are in multiple businesses. There is no plan for distributing the cash at this point; we’ll just hold it on the balance sheet.

question.text: Why is there a need to increase the store count from 1,000 to 2,000 right away?

answer.text: We feel confident about achieving these outcomes and want to transparently communicate our view on growth opportunities in the business without being overly aggressive.

question.text: Is the average order value (AOV) broadly in line with what was seen last quarter?

answer.text: We don't provide that metric so will not be able to comment on that. However, ad revenue is growing for us, and so is the platform fee, which has played a role even in this quarter.

question.text: Can you provide more details on the Hyperpure business and how many restaurants are being serviced?

answer.text: The business is growing well, but we still feel that there's a lot of work to be done in terms of unlocking a much larger TAM. We want to run this business close to breakeven and see if there are new markets or customer segments we can unlock.

question.text: Regarding capex for the stores, how is the deposit money from partners structured?

answer.text: It's in the form of a bank guarantee from the partners and doesn't actually come on our books. We want to be fair to our partners, many of whom are small business owners.
